messageBody:
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> Behalf Of Shane Mingins

> Perhaps some examples of this? I am not proposing an answer
> myself but as a learning experience I would like to see an
> example of where you used something like a mock or in-memory
> database and then got caught out with the "real thing".

Even without any specific example, it's not hard to see the risk in testing
code that is different from what your production machines are running. The
cost of a false positive (tests run but production breaks) is two-fold:

- You need to fix the bug (might be unavoidable)
- You have to pay the price of pushing a defective product in production
(very high, and unacceptable in my book)

Don't get me wrong, I'm not opposed to the idea of mock objects, but it
seems to me that if you want to do more than unit testing with JUnit (which
is a mistake in my opinion), you are *forced* to use mock objects. It's
just the only way to solve this problem.

Mock objects are a fine solution if you have other alternatives and after
you considered them all, mock objects came out as the best solution, but
they come at a price (well, two prices: the one I just mentioned and the
fact that you need to maintain two parallel hierarchies).

> I am thinking that if this happened to me it would show me
> where I should write another test perhaps?

Maybe. Or you would use the exact same test on the real (non-mocked) code
and the bug would show up right away. I know which one I prefer...

> For example what are things that have gone wrong testing
> against Postgresql and then using against Oracle?

Plenty of things can go wrong since the chain is made of so many links:

1) Bug in the database itself (more likely in Postgresql than Oracle IMO)
2) Bug in your code
3) Bug in the JDBC driver (there are many to choose from in boths cases)
4) Bug in how you set up your environment
5) Bug in the mock

By not using a mock, at least you eliminate risk 5).
